BIOS308
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module will cover a broad selection of contemporary issues in biological sciences such as biotechnology, biodiversity loss, sustainability, emerging diseases, and public health amongst many others. Students will select an issue according to their interests and work to apply the knowledge gained over the course of their studies to their chosen topic.

Successful students on this module will gain an appreciation of biological problems facing the modern world and how their skills and knowledge can be a force for change to help mitigate and work towards solving these problems. Students will gain an understanding of their place in the modern world as biological scientists and work to develop skills that will serve society and themselves throughout their career.

The module is delivered via workshops and tutorials. The workshops allow students to identify contemporary issues in biological sciences and then develop the skills to research and address the problems. These workshops build on existing skills and develop further skills around communication to broad audiences, analysing multi-faceted problems and critical thinking. The tutorials are led by academics with subject specific expertise. These tutorials will discuss contemporary problems in biological sciences from different perspectives, allowing students to engage with the topic in a multi-disciplinary approach. The students are assessed on their abilities to communicate science effectively and prepare a long form written piece, detailing the problem and potential solutions for stakeholders.
Educational Aims
• To introduce students to contemporary issues across biological and biomedical sciences
• To develop analytical and critical skills through the analysis of problems in biological and biomedical sciences and making recommendations on how to mitigate and solve these problems
• To develop an understanding of the role biologists have in addressing varied problems in contemporary areas of biological and biomedical sciences
• To further develop communication skills by communicating findings and conclusions via various media to various, broad audiences.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This is a 15-credit 3rd year module that develops students’ understanding of contemporary issues in biological and biomedical sciences. It allows students to build on the knowledge and skills they have developed over the course of their studies and apply their skills to some of the most challenging and relevant issues facing the modern world. The skills developed and utilised in this module are highly valued in many different career pathways and give students the early-career skills they will need to excel as they progress. Students will be assessed by group work in the form of a science communication piece and an individual report.
Outline Syllabus
Contemporary issues in biological sciences

Students will have a choice of issues to focus on which may include but are not limited to; biotechnology, the use of AI and big data in biosciences, climate change & conservation, biodiversity loss, food security & sustainability, emerging diseases, antimicrobial resistance and public health.

The module begins with selecting a topic and proceeds with students working in groups to research their topic. Working in small groups of 4-6 on topics that suit their interests will develop teamworking skills as the students work together to research the issue from a multi-disciplinary approach. Students will be guided in this process by an academic supervisor who will provide guidance throughout the module. Emphasis is placed on drawing information from a variety of sources (academic and non-academic alike) and reflecting on their interpretations of this information, developing digital fluency and confidence.

Workshops will support the students as they develop their ideas and start to work towards solutions. Sessions are designed and delivered by active researchers, promoting research-connected teaching throughout the module.

Examples of topics covered include:
• Contemporary issues in biological sciences
• Regulatory Frameworks
• Ethics and Sustainability
• Information gathering and critical analysis
• Science communication

Students will attend departmental research seminars from a broad choice of research topics. This will enable the students to see the diversity of biological research and how it can be applied to contemporary challenges facing the world. It also affords students the opportunity to engage with active researchers in an authentic way, getting up-to-date information straight from the research community.

Students will be assessed using a science communication piece on an aspect of the problem their group has been working on and an individual report (for example in a consultancy report style eg. https://www.lse.ac.uk/b...ss/consulting/reports).
Teaching and Learning Methods
• Group Working: Students will work in small groups (up to 6 students), each of which tackles a different issue in contemporary biological sciences. The structure of each group will be such that students are rotated through the various roles and in this way they will develop the various skills that make groups successful such as leadership, communication, conflict resolution etc. These groups will be facilitated by an academic in group sessions (typically 2hrs per week) in the early weeks of the module.

• Workshops: Students will attend academic-led workshops in which they will learn how to locate and critically evaluate information from varied sources about issues in Biological and Biomedical Sciences. They will also learn to communicate effectively both with fellow academics and stakeholders in order to produce their solutions.

• Research Seminars: Students will attend seminars, chosen from a broad variety of available research topics across the various research institutes related to biological sciences. They will attend at least 2 seminars during the semester that the module is running, with guidance from the teaching team about what is available and what will be most useful.

• Tutorials: Students will attend tutorials with subject-aligned academic supervisors in which the student’s chosen problems in contemporary biological sciences are introduced and discussed. These tutorials will allow the students to develop their own ideas creatively whilst also providing the guidance of an experienced academic.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Students will be required to produce two items for assessment:

A science communication piece (maximum 1100 words, 40%) on an aspect of the problem their group has analysed. Group work will be partly assessed by members of the group rating each others' contributions (for example by use of Buddycheck).

A concluding consultancy report (maximum 2200 words, 60%), drawn up individually, in which the problem is analysed, conclusions are drawn and solutions suggested and justified.

These assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency, critical thinking and active learning, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their fields. These authentic assessments are problem-based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. Scientific writing and communication is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning and application etc. with active learning central to this task

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 To evaluate major biological problems facing the modern world and a scientist’s role in mitigating/solving these problems.
 LO2 To assess and critically evaluate scientific and non-scientific information pertinent to contemporary issues in biological sciences.
 LO3 To communicate findings via various media and to varied audiences.
 LO4 To develop high-level analytical skills and apply them to a complex problem to generate solutions.
 LO5 To plan, run and produce a consultancy report on a topic in biological and biomedical sciences.
 LO6 To develop professional teamwork skills in the context of solving complex, multi-faceted problems.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Critical analysis
 S2 Communication to lay and professional audiences
 S3 Information gathering and synthesis

BIOS308
Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module will cover a broad selection of contemporary issues in biological sciences such as biotechnology, biodiversity loss, sustainability, emerging diseases, and public health amongst many others. Students will select an issue according to their interests and work to apply the knowledge gained over the course of their studies to their chosen topic.

Successful students on this module will gain an appreciation of biological problems facing the modern world and how their skills and knowledge can be a force for change to help mitigate and work towards solving these problems. Students will gain an understanding of their place in the modern world as biological scientists and work to develop skills that will serve society and themselves throughout their career.

The module is delivered via workshops and tutorials. The workshops allow students to identify contemporary issues in biological sciences and then develop the skills to research and address the problems. These workshops build on existing skills and develop further skills around communication to broad audiences, analysing multi-faceted problems and critical thinking. The tutorials are led by academics with subject specific expertise. These tutorials will discuss contemporary problems in biological sciences from different perspectives, allowing students to engage with the topic in a multi-disciplinary approach. The students are assessed on their abilities to communicate science effectively and prepare a long form written piece, detailing the problem and potential solutions for stakeholders.
Educational Aims
• To introduce students to contemporary issues across biological and biomedical sciences
• To develop analytical and critical skills through the analysis of problems in biological and biomedical sciences and making recommendations on how to mitigate and solve these problems
• To develop an understanding of the role biologists have in addressing varied problems in contemporary areas of biological and biomedical sciences
• To further develop communication skills by communicating findings and conclusions via various media to various, broad audiences.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This is a 15-credit 3rd year module that develops students’ understanding of contemporary issues in biological and biomedical sciences. It allows students to build on the knowledge and skills they have developed over the course of their studies and apply their skills to some of the most challenging and relevant issues facing the modern world. The skills developed and utilised in this module are highly valued in many different career pathways and give students the early-career skills they will need to excel as they progress. Students will be assessed by group work in the form of a science communication piece and an individual report.
Outline Syllabus
Contemporary issues in biological sciences

Students will have a choice of issues to focus on which may include but are not limited to; biotechnology, the use of AI and big data in biosciences, climate change & conservation, biodiversity loss, food security & sustainability, emerging diseases, antimicrobial resistance and public health.

The module begins with selecting a topic and proceeds with students working in groups to research their topic. Working in small groups of 4-6 on topics that suit their interests will develop teamworking skills as the students work together to research the issue from a multi-disciplinary approach. Students will be guided in this process by an academic supervisor who will provide guidance throughout the module. Emphasis is placed on drawing information from a variety of sources (academic and non-academic alike) and reflecting on their interpretations of this information, developing digital fluency and confidence.

Workshops will support the students as they develop their ideas and start to work towards solutions. Sessions are designed and delivered by active researchers, promoting research-connected teaching throughout the module.

Examples of topics covered include:
• Contemporary issues in biological sciences
• Regulatory Frameworks
• Ethics and Sustainability
• Information gathering and critical analysis
• Science communication

Students will attend departmental research seminars from a broad choice of research topics. This will enable the students to see the diversity of biological research and how it can be applied to contemporary challenges facing the world. It also affords students the opportunity to engage with active researchers in an authentic way, getting up-to-date information straight from the research community.

Students will be assessed using a science communication piece on an aspect of the problem their group has been working on and an individual report (for example in a consultancy report style eg. https://www.lse.ac.uk/b...ss/consulting/reports).
Teaching and Learning Methods
• Group Working: Students will work in small groups (up to 6 students), each of which tackles a different issue in contemporary biological sciences. The structure of each group will be such that students are rotated through the various roles and in this way they will develop the various skills that make groups successful such as leadership, communication, conflict resolution etc. These groups will be facilitated by an academic in group sessions (typically 2hrs per week) in the early weeks of the module.

• Workshops: Students will attend academic-led workshops in which they will learn how to locate and critically evaluate information from varied sources about issues in Biological and Biomedical Sciences. They will also learn to communicate effectively both with fellow academics and stakeholders in order to produce their solutions.

• Research Seminars: Students will attend seminars, chosen from a broad variety of available research topics across the various research institutes related to biological sciences. They will attend at least 2 seminars during the semester that the module is running, with guidance from the teaching team about what is available and what will be most useful.

• Tutorials: Students will attend tutorials with subject-aligned academic supervisors in which the student’s chosen problems in contemporary biological sciences are introduced and discussed. These tutorials will allow the students to develop their own ideas creatively whilst also providing the guidance of an experienced academic.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Students will be required to produce two items for assessment:

A science communication piece (maximum 1100 words, 40%) on an aspect of the problem their group has analysed. Group work will be partly assessed by members of the group rating each others' contributions (for example by use of Buddycheck).

A concluding consultancy report (maximum 2200 words, 60%), drawn up individually, in which the problem is analysed, conclusions are drawn and solutions suggested and justified.

These assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency, critical thinking and active learning, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their fields. These authentic assessments are problem-based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. Scientific writing and communication is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning and application etc. with active learning central to this task

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 To evaluate major biological problems facing the modern world and a scientist’s role in mitigating/solving these problems.
 LO2 To assess and critically evaluate scientific and non-scientific information pertinent to contemporary issues in biological sciences.
 LO3 To communicate findings via various media and to varied audiences.
 LO4 To develop high-level analytical skills and apply them to a complex problem to generate solutions.
 LO5 To plan, run and produce a consultancy report on a topic in biological and biomedical sciences.
 LO6 To develop professional teamwork skills in the context of solving complex, multi-faceted problems.
Skills

 S3 Information gathering and synthesis

Notes
New module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2024, starting with year 1.

Overview

Overview
This module will cover a broad selection of contemporary issues in biological sciences such as biotechnology, biodiversity loss, sustainability, emerging diseases, and public health amongst many others. Students will select an issue according to their interests and work to apply the knowledge gained over the course of their studies to their chosen topic.

Successful students on this module will gain an appreciation of biological problems facing the modern world and how their skills and knowledge can be a force for change to help mitigate and work towards solving these problems. Students will gain an understanding of their place in the modern world as biological scientists and work to develop skills that will serve society and themselves throughout their career.

The module is delivered via workshops and tutorials. The workshops allow students to identify contemporary issues in biological sciences and then develop the skills to research and address the problems. These workshops build on existing skills and develop further skills around communication to broad audiences, analysing multi-faceted problems and critical thinking. The tutorials are led by academics with subject specific expertise. These tutorials will discuss contemporary problems in biological sciences from different perspectives, allowing students to engage with the topic in a multi-disciplinary approach. The students are assessed on their abilities to communicate science effectively and prepare a long form written piece, detailing the problem and potential solutions for stakeholders.
Educational Aims
• To introduce students to contemporary issues across biological and biomedical sciences
• To develop analytical and critical skills through the analysis of problems in biological and biomedical sciences and making recommendations on how to mitigate and solve these problems
• To develop an understanding of the role biologists have in addressing varied problems in contemporary areas of biological and biomedical sciences
• To further develop communication skills by communicating findings and conclusions via various media to various, broad audiences.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This is a 15-credit 3rd year module that develops students’ understanding of contemporary issues in biological and biomedical sciences. It allows students to build on the knowledge and skills they have developed over the course of their studies and apply their skills to some of the most challenging and relevant issues facing the modern world. The skills developed and utilised in this module are highly valued in many different career pathways and give students the early-career skills they will need to excel as they progress. Students will be assessed by group work in the form of a science communication piece and an individual report.
Outline Syllabus
Contemporary issues in biological sciences

Students will have a choice of issues to focus on which may include but are not limited to; biotechnology, the use of AI and big data in biosciences, climate change & conservation, biodiversity loss, food security & sustainability, emerging diseases, antimicrobial resistance and public health.

The module begins with selecting a topic and proceeds with students working in groups to research their topic. Working in small groups of 4-6 on topics that suit their interests will develop teamworking skills as the students work together to research the issue from a multi-disciplinary approach. Students will be guided in this process by an academic supervisor who will provide guidance throughout the module. Emphasis is placed on drawing information from a variety of sources (academic and non-academic alike) and reflecting on their interpretations of this information, developing digital fluency and confidence.

Workshops will support the students as they develop their ideas and start to work towards solutions. Sessions are designed and delivered by active researchers, promoting research-connected teaching throughout the module.

Examples of topics covered include:
• Contemporary issues in biological sciences
• Regulatory Frameworks
• Ethics and Sustainability
• Information gathering and critical analysis
• Science communication

Students will attend departmental research seminars from a broad choice of research topics. This will enable the students to see the diversity of biological research and how it can be applied to contemporary challenges facing the world. It also affords students the opportunity to engage with active researchers in an authentic way, getting up-to-date information straight from the research community.

Students will be assessed using a science communication piece on an aspect of the problem their group has been working on and an individual report (for example in a consultancy report style eg. https://www.lse.ac.uk/b...ss/consulting/reports).
Teaching and Learning Methods
• Group Working: Students will work in small groups (up to 6 students), each of which tackles a different issue in contemporary biological sciences. The structure of each group will be such that students are rotated through the various roles and in this way they will develop the various skills that make groups successful such as leadership, communication, conflict resolution etc. These groups will be facilitated by an academic in group sessions (typically 2hrs per week) in the early weeks of the module.

• Workshops: Students will attend academic-led workshops in which they will learn how to locate and critically evaluate information from varied sources about issues in Biological and Biomedical Sciences. They will also learn to communicate effectively both with fellow academics and stakeholders in order to produce their solutions.

• Research Seminars: Students will attend seminars, chosen from a broad variety of available research topics across the various research institutes related to biological sciences. They will attend at least 2 seminars during the semester that the module is running, with guidance from the teaching team about what is available and what will be most useful.

• Tutorials: Students will attend tutorials with subject-aligned academic supervisors in which the student’s chosen problems in contemporary biological sciences are introduced and discussed. These tutorials will allow the students to develop their own ideas creatively whilst also providing the guidance of an experienced academic.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Students will be required to produce two items for assessment:

A science communication piece (maximum 1100 words, 40%) on an aspect of the problem their group has analysed. Group work will be partly assessed by members of the group rating each others' contributions (for example by use of Buddycheck).

A concluding consultancy report (maximum 2200 words, 60%), drawn up individually, in which the problem is analysed, conclusions are drawn and solutions suggested and justified.

These assessments enhance professionalism, digital fluency, critical thinking and active learning, skills highly sought after by graduate employers. Additionally, we are creating confident graduates who will excel in their fields. These authentic assessments are problem-based and research-connected and the skills for completion are taught through active learning. Scientific writing and communication is highly authentic and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, project planning and application etc. with active learning central to this task

Reassessment will use the same format, but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 To evaluate major biological problems facing the modern world and a scientist’s role in mitigating/solving these problems.
 LO2 To assess and critically evaluate scientific and non-scientific information pertinent to contemporary issues in biological sciences.
 LO3 To communicate findings via various media and to varied audiences.
 LO4 To develop high-level analytical skills and apply them to a complex problem to generate solutions.
 LO5 To plan, run and produce a consultancy report on a topic in biological and biomedical sciences.
 LO6 To develop professional teamwork skills in the context of solving complex, multi-faceted problems.
